articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Zarxio, Its First Biosimilar Drug
articles.snippet: The approval paves the way for alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs to go on the market.
articles.abstract: The approval paves the way for alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs to go on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first so-called biosimilar drug for use in the United States, paving the way for less expensive alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Paying Tribute to Thomas Stanley and His ‘Millionaire Next Door’
articles.snippet: Mr. Stanley, who was killed in a recent car accident, wrote a book with William Danko that became a classic in personal finance by showing ordinary people how to accumulate assets.
articles.abstract: Mr. Stanley, who was killed in a recent car accident, wrote a book with William Danko that became a classic in personal finance by showing ordinary people how to accumulate assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rich are different from you and me, though maybe not quite like we think they are.

articles.headline: Menendez Is to Face Corruption Charges, U.S. Official Says
articles.snippet: The Justice Department expects to charge Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, in an inquiry that has focused on his ties to a Florida eye doctor, an official said.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department expects to charge Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, in an inquiry that has focused on his ties to a Florida eye doctor, an official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing to file corruption charges against Senator Robert Menendez, a scrappy 61-year-old veteran of New Jersey politics, after a two-year investigation into allegations that he accepted gifts and lavish vacations in exchange for political favors for a longtime friend and political benefactor.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Ontario’s Beer Bottleneck Is Under Siege by Brewers and Buyers
articles.snippet: Retailers, beer makers and the provincial government are increasingly skeptical of the longstanding retail system for beer sales.
articles.abstract: Retailers, beer makers and the provincial government are increasingly skeptical of the longstanding retail system for beer sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Brewers Retail has sold beer pretty much the same way since it opened 88 years ago.

articles.headline: The New Jobs Report Shows Janet Yellen’s Quandary in a Nutshell
articles.snippet: Some numbers suggest the Fed should raise interest rates, but wages are still stagnant, and the number of people in the labor force just shrank.
articles.abstract: Some numbers suggest the Fed should raise interest rates, but wages are still stagnant, and the number of people in the labor force just shrank.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest decision that Janet Yellen has faced in her year-old Federal Reserve chairmanship was laid bare in a single report on the domestic job market released Friday.

articles.headline: Germany Sets Gender Quota in Boardrooms
articles.snippet: Germany passed a law Friday that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.
articles.abstract: Germany passed a law Friday that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany on Friday became the latest and most significant country so far to commit to improving the representation of women on corporate boards, passing a law that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Sex Expert’s Secret Is Out, and China’s Open to It
articles.snippet: After a blogger accused her of being a closeted lesbian, Li Yinhe, an advocate of freewheeling sexuality in China, announced that her partner of 17 years is a transgender man.
articles.abstract: After a blogger accused her of being a closeted lesbian, Li Yinhe, an advocate of freewheeling sexuality in China, announced that her partner of 17 years is a transgender man.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Li Yinhe, China’s leading advocate of freewheeling sexuality, has been shocking this outwardly prudish nation for three decades.

articles.headline: A Third Blast on Oil Trains Stirs Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A string of fiery accidents prompts some to question whether safety upgrades are good enough or coming soon enough as rail transportation of oil keeps growing.
articles.abstract: A string of fiery accidents prompts some to question whether safety upgrades are good enough or coming soon enough as rail transportation of oil keeps growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the third time in less than a month, a train carrying flammable crude oil has derailed and burst into flames, prompting questions over whether stricter measures being considered to ensure their safety will be enough.

articles.headline: Obama, at Selma Memorial, Says, ‘We Know the March Is Not Yet Over’
articles.snippet: In an address on the spot of what became known as “Bloody Sunday” in Alabama 50 years ago, President Obama rejected the notion that race relations had not improved since then.
articles.abstract: In an address on the spot of what became known as “Bloody Sunday” in Alabama 50 years ago, President Obama rejected the notion that race relations had not improved since then.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — As a new generation struggles over race and power in America, President Obama and a host of political figures from both parties came here on Saturday, to the site of one of the most searing days of the civil rights era, to reflect on how far the country has come and how far it still has to go.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: McDonald’s Seeks Its Fast-Food Soul
articles.snippet: A new chief executive took over last week, inheriting a weakened company that is under pressure to be both cheap and high-quality.
articles.abstract: A new chief executive took over last week, inheriting a weakened company that is under pressure to be both cheap and high-quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: McDonald’s is having an identity crisis.

articles.headline: Move Over Mao: Beloved ‘Papa Xi’ Awes China
articles.snippet: Not since Mao Zedong dominated the nation with his masterly blend of populism, fervor and fear has a Chinese leader commanded as much public awe as President Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: Not since Mao Zedong dominated the nation with his masterly blend of populism, fervor and fear has a Chinese leader commanded as much public awe as President Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The must-see tourist sights of the Chinese capital form a grandiose circuit: the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, Tiananmen Square and, for early birds willing to brave long lines, the mausoleum of Mao Zedong.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: At the Fed in 2009, Rolling the Dice in a Crisis
articles.snippet: Newly released transcripts from Federal Reserve Board meetings in 2009 cover some of the darkest days of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Newly released transcripts from Federal Reserve Board meetings in 2009 cover some of the darkest days of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve Board have earned accolades from all corners for the extraordinary actions they took to rescue the financial system in 2009. While 2008 was the Fed’s annus horribilis, exposing how unaware the central bank had been of the risks building in the financial system, 2009 was its year of redemption.

articles.headline: In Greece, Desperate Times and Offbeat Measures
articles.snippet: Athens is coming up with radical ways to fill its shortfall as it nears a deadline to meet financial obligations, including wiring tourists, students and housekeepers to catch tax evaders.
articles.abstract: Athens is coming up with radical ways to fill its shortfall as it nears a deadline to meet financial obligations, including wiring tourists, students and housekeepers to catch tax evaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite the European accord last month to extend a financial lifeline to Greece, Athens is rapidly running out of cash.

articles.headline: On the Case at Mount Sinai, It’s Dr. Data
articles.snippet: Jeffrey Hammerbacher, who started Facebook’s data science team, now uses his skills to improve medical treatments, a switch inspired by his own health crisis.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey Hammerbacher, who started Facebook’s data science team, now uses his skills to improve medical treatments, a switch inspired by his own health crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Hammerbacher is a number cruncher — a Harvard math major who went from a job as a Wall Street quant to a key role at Facebook to a founder of a successful data start-up.

articles.headline: African Training Exercise Turns Urgent as Threats Grow
articles.snippet: New ties between Boko Haram and the Islamic State have reinforced American and European concerns that have led to the training of African troops.
articles.abstract: New ties between Boko Haram and the Islamic State have reinforced American and European concerns that have led to the training of African troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAO, Chad — An oath of allegiance from Boko Haram, the Nigeria-based militant group, to the Islamic State on Saturday reinforces Western fears that the terrorist group is growing beyond its base in Iraq and Syria. These worries have prompted American and allied commandos to rush to train African counterterrorism troops to fight extremists on the continent.

articles.headline: Ferguson Became Symbol, but Bias Knows No Border
articles.snippet: The unfairness in Ferguson’s court system that is highlighted by a Justice Department report is not limited to it or even to Missouri.
articles.abstract: The unfairness in Ferguson’s court system that is highlighted by a Justice Department report is not limited to it or even to Missouri.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the shooting of Michael Brown had taken place about 500 yards to the southeast, he would have died not in Ferguson, Mo., but in the neighboring city of Jennings. The court system there, which is overseen by a white judge but has almost exclusively black defendants, routinely sends people to jail for failure to pay minor traffic fines, a new lawsuit alleges.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Shaila Dewan and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Who Spewed That Abuse? Anonymous Yik Yak App Isn’t Telling
articles.snippet: Yik Yak, a social media app that serves as a local bulletin board, has proved popular especially on college campuses, but the cover of anonymity it offers allows for some unfettered nastiness.
articles.abstract: Yik Yak, a social media app that serves as a local bulletin board, has proved popular especially on college campuses, but the cover of anonymity it offers allows for some unfettered nastiness.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a brief recess in an honors course at Eastern Michigan University last fall, a teaching assistant approached the class’s three female professors. “I think you need to see this,” she said, tapping the icon of a furry yak on her iPhone.

articles.headline: Job Growth for Hispanics Is Outpacing Other Groups
articles.snippet: Of all the country’s major racial and ethnic groups, only Hispanics, as of late last year, had returned to their unemployment levels before the recession, according to a recent economic report.
articles.abstract: Of all the country’s major racial and ethnic groups, only Hispanics, as of late last year, had returned to their unemployment levels before the recession, according to a recent economic report.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the economy adding nearly 300,000 jobs in February, it’s clear that the labor market is on a roll. And, perhaps surprisingly, there is no group for whom that is truer than Hispanics.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Is Divided as Budget Bills Start Piling Up
articles.snippet: Pay cuts for Medicare physicians, the Highway Trust Fund and the federal Export-Import Bank are among the budget measures that a Republican-controlled Congress will be faced with passing this year.
articles.abstract: Pay cuts for Medicare physicians, the Highway Trust Fund and the federal Export-Import Bank are among the budget measures that a Republican-controlled Congress will be faced with passing this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In their first major test of governing this year, Republicans stumbled, faltered — and nearly shut down the Department of Homeland Security.

articles.headline: Square Expands Its Reach Into Small-Business Services
articles.snippet: The payments start-up has gone beyond its credit card reader and introduced new products in the last year, including two new services that it says will help small businesses.
articles.abstract: The payments start-up has gone beyond its credit card reader and introduced new products in the last year, including two new services that it says will help small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is Square?

articles.headline: At Goldman Sachs, Stress Test Results Could Endanger an Important Profit Source
articles.snippet: After Goldman Sachs’s poor performance on Federal Reserve stress tests, analysts and investors are worried that the bank could be barred from buying back its own stock or increasing dividends.
articles.abstract: After Goldman Sachs’s poor performance on Federal Reserve stress tests, analysts and investors are worried that the bank could be barred from buying back its own stock or increasing dividends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Concerns have emerged that Goldman Sachs — long the leader on Wall Street — may lose an important engine of profitability.

articles.headline: Provider’s Dispute With Viacom Highlights Skirmish Over the Cable Bundle
articles.snippet: As the television industry transitions in the digital age, cable profits are increasingly tied to broadband rather than video.
articles.abstract: As the television industry transitions in the digital age, cable profits are increasingly tied to broadband rather than video.
articles.lead_paragraph: An email from a lobbyist landed in Eric Rouse‘s inbox one afternoon last December, catapulting Mr. Rouse, a commissioner of rural Lenoir County in North Carolina, into the middle of one of the fiercest battles being waged across the media business.

articles.headline: Race in Iraq and Syria to Record and Shield Art Falling to ISIS
articles.snippet: Archaeologists and preservationists lament that in areas held by the Islamic State, there is little they can do but document the destruction.
articles.abstract: Archaeologists and preservationists lament that in areas held by the Islamic State, there is little they can do but document the destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In those areas of Iraq and Syria controlled by the Islamic State, residents are furtively recording on their cellphones damage done to antiquities by the extremist group. In northern Syria, museum curators have covered precious mosaics with sealant and sandbags.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Faces Test of Record as Women’s Advocate
articles.snippet: Donations to the Clinton Foundation from nations with poor records on women’s rights are causing problems for a candidate expected to run in part as the embodiment of women’s aspirations.
articles.abstract: Donations to the Clinton Foundation from nations with poor records on women’s rights are causing problems for a candidate expected to run in part as the embodiment of women’s aspirations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was supposed to be a carefully planned anniversary to mark one of the most important and widely praised moments in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s political career — and to remind the country, ahead of a likely 2016 presidential campaign, about her long record as a champion for the rights of women and girls.

articles.headline: Apple Watch Success Will Hinge on Apps
articles.snippet: Apple designed its device, which will be available for preorder on April 10, to suit the tastes of various users, from fitness buffs to collectors of luxury watches.
articles.abstract: Apple designed its device, which will be available for preorder on April 10, to suit the tastes of various users, from fitness buffs to collectors of luxury watches.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The value of a wristwatch is typically defined by its materials, design, features and brand. For the new Apple Watch, all those factors will apply, but so will something else: apps.

articles.headline: Mall Owner Simon Property Bids for Rival Macerich to Aim at High-End Shoppers
articles.snippet: Shares of Macerich were trading above Simon’s hostile bid, suggesting that some investors believe the final price will go higher.
articles.abstract: Shares of Macerich were trading above Simon’s hostile bid, suggesting that some investors believe the final price will go higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across America, many shopping malls are dying. Stagnant middle-class incomes, overbuilt retail space and competitors like Amazon.com and Costco are turning these former fixtures of the retail landscape into abandoned boxes, devoid of clients or customers.

articles.headline: Unions Suffer Latest Defeat in Midwest With Signing of Wisconsin Measure
articles.snippet: The so-called right-to-work law prevents organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues, making Wisconsin the 25th state to adopt such a policy.
articles.abstract: The so-called right-to-work law prevents organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues, making Wisconsin the 25th state to adopt such a policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — For decades, states across the South, Great Plains and Rocky Mountains enacted policies that prevented organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues or fees. But the industrial Midwest resisted.

articles.headline: In Chávez, Maduro Trusts, Maybe to His Detriment and Venezuela’s
articles.snippet: As an economic crisis worsens, what was once President Nicolás Maduro’s greatest advantage — loyalty to his predecessor — may be his greatest handicap.
articles.abstract: As an economic crisis worsens, what was once President Nicolás Maduro’s greatest advantage — loyalty to his predecessor — may be his greatest handicap.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — He thunders about conspiracies and assassination plots. He says that he sleeps with both eyes open. Few Venezuelans even know where he lives.
